title: Accelerating Improvements in HIV Prevention and Care in the United States Through the HIV Care Continuum Initiative

enrichment.summary: This executive order establishes a federal initiative to improve HIV prevention and care in the United States by focusing on increasing HIV testing, treatment, and services along the HIV care continuum. It sets up a working group to coordinate federal efforts, track progress, and recommend ways to better address gaps in diagnosing and treating HIV to reduce new infections and improve health outcomes.
potential_concerns: Increased coordination under interagency-coordination may create bureaucratic delays that slow the rapid deployment of HIV prevention and care services to marginalized groups such as low-income individuals and racial minorities.

Expanding HIV testing and early treatment access relying on ACA provisions may leave uninsured individuals or those in states with limited Medicaid expansion without timely care, exacerbating health disparities.
Privacy concerns may arise for LGBTQ+ individuals and racial/ethnic minority groups regarding sensitive HIV-related health data collected and shared across federal agencies.

The focus on evidence-based strategies may inadvertently overlook culturally tailored interventions needed by African American and Hispanic/Latino communities, limiting effectiveness among these groups.
Veterans living with HIV could face challenges if coordination and resource allocation do not sufficiently integrate Department of Veterans Affairs services with broader federal HIV care initiatives.
